title: What is the role of love in Dante's poetry, and how does it relate to personal experience versus literary convention?
first_phrase: In this text, Valli is responding to doubts expressed by Bruers about his thesis on the symbolism of the Divine Comedy. Valli acknowledges the difficulty of identifying the true nature of the love represented in the poetry of the Fedeli d'Amore. He argues that for Dante, the "material" of love was opposed to its "form" in a scholastic sense. He also thanks an article's author for introducing him to the works of Rossetti, who he credits with inspiring his own exploration of symbolism.
content: La materia amorosa (cioè i ricordi, le impressioni, le parole dell'amore) costituivano, diremmo noi, il materiale al quale l'idea iniziatica dava forma, col quale cioè costruiva la vera poesia. Ora io non ho mai negato (Il Linguaggio Segreto, pag. 417 e seg.) che questa gente sia stata innamorata, il che vuol dire che la materia amorosa l'abbia tratta da esperienza diretta e personale oltre che da ricordi letterari e da imitazione di altri. Ma quando era esperienza personale e quando ricordo letterario e imitazione? Difficile dirlo ed è cosa da sentire caso per caso.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the materials of love, such as memories, impressions, and words of affection, were transformed by the initiatic idea into the true poetry. While some inspiration may have come from personal experience, literature, or imitation, it is difficult to differentiate. Nonetheless, the works of Dante and others bear witness to the transformation of direct inspiration into conventional thought, resulting in the creation of literary elements.
